repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - Second Village Infrastructure
            Project and Kecamatan Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Village Infrastructure
            Project had a satisfactory outcome and had a substantial
            institutional development impact, although its
            sustainability cannot be evaluated. The performances of both
            the Bank and the Borrower were satisfactory. The Kecamatan
            Development Project had a moderately satisfactory outcome
            with substantial institutional development impact although
            it too has a sustainability that cannot be evaluated. Here
            also the performances of both the Bank and the Borrower were
            satisfactory. Six lessons were suggested by these two
            projects: 1) Translate the project's poverty objectives
            into clearly defined outcomes and outputs in the Project
            Appraisal Document that can be monitored and evaluated. 2)
            Project management has to intervene at the community to
            support poverty and gender issues and challenge the status.
            3) Develop an infrastructure maintenance strategy that
            addresses the total community infrastructure. 4) Reduce the
            costs -including time spent in meetings -- of beneficiary
            participation as the number of program's increases. 5)
            Heed past lessons in rural finance: Effective and
            sustainable rural finance calls for an institutional
            capacity to evaluate debt capacity, a sustainable
            institutional home, low costs, and strong incentives for the
            borrower(s) to remain in good standing. In the Kecamatan
            project it was a mistake to force an economic loans
            component into a grants program outside a carefully prepared
            rural finance intervention. 6) Define at the outset some
            kind of baseline (and related milestones) regarding the
            level of corruption, so as to measure progress.

abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome was highly
            satisfactory, and project sustainability is likely. Both
            World Bank and Borrower performances are highly satisfactory
            overall. Lessons learned from the First Village
            Infrastructure Project (report no. 19099)(ICR) remain valid.
            This project aimed at institutionalizing the VIP procedures,
            and some lessons worth noting include: Programmatic and
            flexible approaches and a franchise approach used to
            replicate small-scale assistance, when shown to be feasible,
            need to be evolved for a longer-term program. That is,
            self-targeting instead of village targeting is preferable so
            that assistance offered gets directed where demand is
            demonstrated, and will benefit poorer segments within
            villages. Likewise, the involvement of local officials
            should be expanded rather than remain restricted.
            Supervision reports should be honest about problems; this
            reporting should be seen in context and not penalized. Road
            maintenance and design should vary depending on
            environmental circumstances and road function. Latrine and
            septic tank use and maintenance will only improve once
            hygiene instruction and sanitation importance is taught to
            the public. Muslim women will participate in development
            activities if the program is well advertised and they know
            they are eligible. Beneficiaries will take advantage of the
            opportunities offered by programs if they are involved in
            program design. Monitoring is better assisted by local
            agencies and local communities.

abstracts.cdata!:
This Second Village Infrastructure
            Project is classified as a targeted poverty reduction
            intervention. The main objective is to build small
            infrastructures in poor rural villages on Java and Sumatra.
            This also creates cash employment for villagers. Secondary
            objectives are to increase decentralization and community
            participation. The project will provide a grant to each of
            2,600 of the poorest villagers on Java and Sumatra for
            building local infrastructures. The villagers will decide
            what to build, from a menu of choices, and will build it by
            themselves, the workers being paid by output. Much of the
            grant may be used to purchase materials. Some equipment will
            be leased. Field engineers will assist the villagers to plan
            and implement the works, while also handling financial
            aspects. Senior engineers and a project management unit will
            be in charge of the overall planning, coordination and
            implementation management.
